description: Possibly a corruption of cage, from Old French.

entries.meaning: (falconry) A circular frame on which cadgers carry hawks for sale.

verbs.description: cadge (third-person singular simple present cadges, present participle cadging or cadgin, simple past and past participle cadged)

examples: Are ye gannin te cadge a lift of yoer fatha?

entries.meaning: (US, Britain, slang) To obtain something by wit or guile; to convince people to do something they might not normally do.
examples: Synonyms: scrounge, bum; see also Thesaurus:scrounge

entries.meaning: To carry hawks and other birds of prey.
(UK, Scotland, dialect) To carry, as a burden.
(UK, Scotland, dialect) To hawk or peddle, as fish, poultry, etc.
(UK, Scotland, dialect) To intrude or live on another meanly; to beg.
examples: Cadging on the fly is a profitable occupation in the vicinity of bathing places, and large towns. A person of this description frequently gets many shillings in the course of the day
